We‚Äôre Ready to Help The CRA & CRF team is composed of association and industry professionals who are wholly dedicated to supporting Colorado‚Äôs restaurant community through advocacy, member resources, communication, and, quite often (and with great pleasure), dining in Centennial State restaurants. Reach out any time at info@corestaurant.org or get in touch with a specific member of the team through the information below. Political slogan appears on one Alachua restaurant‚Äôs menu Skip to content Download Apps Newsletter Tell Us Something Good Be Our Guest Meet the Team Advertise with Us Submit Photos and Videos Watch Live Video News First Alert Weather Sports Features Hurricane HQ Telemundo Contact Us Community InvestigateTV Home Watch Live News Gainesville Ocala Lake City State National Crime Politics Education Health Good News Sponsored First Alert Weather Hurricane HQ 24/7 Live Weather Radar Weather Maps Forecast Graphics Tropics Graphics First Alert Explained Weather 101 Sports Florida Gators High School Scholar Athlete Russell Report TV20 Coaches Spotlight Junior College Chomp List Submit Your Sports Photos Espa√±ol Contact Us News Tips Meet the Team Download Our Apps Advertise Employment Advertise Features Bright Futures One Class at a Time Hometown Heroes Paige's Kitchen Tech Tuesday FL Man Adventures Adopt A Pet Wildlife Wednesday Fitness Community Community Calendar Contests TV20 Newsletter Sign-Up Submit Photos and Videos Tell Us Something Good Programming Schedule Zeam - News Streams Gray DC Bureau NextGen TV Zeam - News Streams InvestigateTV Watching Your Wallet Be Our Guest Sky20 Drone Your Local Chamber Your Local Experts HealthCARES Watch ABC Online PowerNation Circle Country Digital Marketing Political slogan appears on one Alachua restaurant‚Äôs menu Political slogan appears on one Alachua restaurant‚Äôs menu By Kristin Chase Published : Dec. 29, 2021 at 6:55 PM EST Email This Link Share on Facebook Share on X (formerly Twitter) Share on Pinterest Share on LinkedIn ALACHUA, Fla. (WCJB) - ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs Go Brandon‚Äù is a political slogan that has become popular across the nation and used as a code for profanity. Conestogas Restaurant added a special to the menu called ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs Go Brandon.‚Äù The special includes fried corn nuggets and barbecue chicken empanadas. The slogan originated in October at a NASCAR race and has become widely used against President Joe Biden. It is now being chanted at presidential appearances and political rallies, and has been made into signs and apparel. One former customer says he does not agree with Conestogas using the slogan on their menu. ‚ÄúWhen you start making political statements like that on your menu board then I got to draw the line somewhere and that‚Äôs where I drew it. I decided not to go there any longer‚Äù says J.C. Thomas. Another diner says the name of the special actually drew him to the restaurant. ‚ÄúJust pure curiosity because there is a little bit of controversy with it. I think everybody just needs to lighten up a little and deal with it. It‚Äôs First Amendment. If you don‚Äôt like it, don‚Äôt come here‚Äù says Craig Terry. The co-owner of Conestogas, Melissa Robertson, says that sales of the special have been high since she created it. She emphasized they do have employees who support President Joe Biden and are fine with the special. Saying, as Americans, they have the right to free speech. Copyright 2021 WCJB. All rights reserved. Click here to subscribe to our newsletter. Site search Search Subscribe Log In My Account Log Out Obits Sports Events Crime Jobs Classifieds Games Archives Shop We secretly dined at Conestoga Restaurant: Here's a review for our IncognEATo series Share this Facebook Twitter WhatsApp SMS Email Print Copy article link Today's  LNP e-Newspaper September 10, 2025 57¬∞ Home News Local News We secretly dined at Conestoga Restaurant: Here's a review for our IncognEATo series LANCASTERONLINE | Staff Jul 27, 2017 Jul 27, 2017 Facebook Twitter WhatsApp SMS Email Buy Now Feeling hungry? Conestoga Restaurant's Uncle Crabby Bleu burger is a half-pound of satisfaction -- with lump crabmeat, bleu cheese, avocado, bacon, lettuce, tomato, caramelized onions and ancho chipotle mayo on top. STAFF Facebook Twitter WhatsApp SMS Email Print Copy article link There are evenings ‚Äî especially summer evenings, and especially Friday evenings in the summer ‚Äî when the leftovers from Monday and Tuesday dinners are picked over and the thought of a quick takeout pizza just doesn‚Äôt appeal. One of our go-to spots in times like these has become the Conestoga Restaurant just on the city‚Äôs eastern edge. Initially, we chose it because it‚Äôs relatively close to home (we‚Äôve all done that, with varying degrees of satisfaction). But we keep going back because the food, especially in the past couple of years, hasn‚Äôt disappointed us yet. Service can be leisurely, especially during a busy night on the outdoor patio. But if you‚Äôre sitting amidst the landscaping that‚Äôs nicely matured, screening East King Street traffic but still providing views of the old Bridgeport bridge, and you‚Äôre watching birds flit along the Conestoga River, there are worse ways to relax and nurse a drink while waiting for your meal. A recent Saturday visit was a bonus: one of the restaurant‚Äôs monthly Greek Weeks, with Greek specialties such as pastichio on the menu. That‚Äôs what I always choose: The mix of pasta, ground beef and bechamel sauce is something I don‚Äôt make for myself at home, so it‚Äôs a special treat when I find it out and about. On this visit, the serving of pastichio ($16) was a bit smaller than I‚Äôve had in the past (it‚Äôs always been enough for two meals, but I polished this off with no problem). Still, it was flavorful and delicious, and I didn‚Äôt have to stand in the kitchen on a 90-degree day to make it. My dining partner opted, as usual, for a Conestoga Restaurant burger. There are 10 standbys on the menu, and I think we‚Äôve tried them all at one time or another. Prices range from $12 (The All-American Burger) to $18 (The Double-Bacon Cheeseburger) for the half-pound sandwich served with lettuce, tomato, homemade pickles and homemade Conestoga chips . This visit? The Uncle Crabby Bleu ($15), grilled to perfection (medium) with lump crab, Danish bleu cheese, avocado, bacon, lettuce, tomato, caramelized onions and ancho-chipotle mayo, piled on a toasted roll. If that sounds like a lot, it is. I need two bites to get through the full height, especially with all the extra goodies piled on top. Here‚Äôs how you know it‚Äôs filling: My dining companion urged me to have some of the accompanying potato chips because the burger and chips were just too much together ‚Äî and that never happens. To pass the time while we waited for food, my companion had a Goose Island IPA ($6.50), while I had an herbal lemonade ($9): fresh-squeezed lemons, Patron Citronge and infused herbs. That‚Äôs not always on the cocktail menu but if it is, grab one. They‚Äôre not to be missed. Service took a bit of waiting ‚Äî the patio was absolutely packed ‚Äî but it nevertheless was efficient, cheerful, accurate and welcoming. It‚Äôs not a fancy atmosphere, and it‚Äôs not elaborate food, but it‚Äôs our sweet spot, with good food and drink. At the end of a long, long week, there are few treats any nicer. Newsletter Success!
